concepts.title: Momentum
concepts.body: Momentum is a measure of how difficult it is to stop a moving object and is defined as the product of an object's mass and velocity.

concepts.title: Calculating Momentum
concepts.body:
The momentum \(p\) of a moving object is calculated using:

$$p = mv$$
where \(m\) is mass and \(v\) is velocity.

concepts.title: Vector Nature of Momentum
concepts.body: Momentum is a **vector quantity**, meaning it has both magnitude and direction. The direction of momentum is the same as the direction of motion.

concepts.title: Examples of Momentum as a Vector
concepts.body: Objects moving in opposite directions have momenta in opposite directions, even if their speeds are the same.

concepts.title: Vector Diagrams for Momentum
concepts.body: Vector diagrams can be used to illustrate the relationship between **initial momentum**, **final momentum**, and **change in momentum**.

concepts.title: Change in Momentum
concepts.body:
The change in momentum is given by:

$$\Delta p = p_f - p_i$$

concepts.title: Newton’s Second Law (Momentum Form)
concepts.body: The net force acting on an object is equal to the rate of change of momentum.

concepts.title: Newton’s Second Law in Symbols
concepts.body:
Newton’s Second Law can be written as:

$$\vec{F}_{net} = \frac{\Delta \vec{p}}{\Delta t}$$

concepts.title: Force and Change in Momentum
concepts.body: A larger net force produces a greater change in momentum. For the same change in momentum, increasing the time interval reduces the force.

concepts.title: Change in Momentum in Different Motions
concepts.body: Momentum increases when velocity increases, decreases when velocity decreases, and reverses direction when the object changes direction (e.g. a soccer ball kicked back).

concepts.title: Systems in Physics
concepts.body: A **system** refers to one or more objects being studied together.

concepts.title: Internal and External Forces
concepts.body: Internal forces act between objects within a system, while external forces act on the system from outside.

concepts.title: Isolated Systems
concepts.body: An isolated system is one in which the net external force acting on the system is zero.

concepts.title: Law of Conservation of Momentum
concepts.body: The total linear momentum of an isolated system remains constant (is conserved).

concepts.title: Types of Collisions
concepts.body: Collisions can be **elastic** or **inelastic**, depending on whether kinetic energy is conserved.

concepts.title: Kinetic Energy in Collisions
concepts.body: Kinetic energy is conserved only in **elastic collisions**.

concepts.title: Momentum in One-Dimensional Collisions
concepts.body: The conservation of momentum can be applied to collisions of two objects moving along a straight line using an appropriate sign convention.

concepts.title: Impulse
concepts.body:
Impulse is defined as the product of the net force and the contact time:

$$J = F_{net}\Delta t$$

concepts.title: Impulse as a Vector Quantity
concepts.body: Impulse is a **vector quantity** and has the same direction as the net force.

concepts.title: Impulse–Momentum Theorem
concepts.body:
Impulse is equal to the change in momentum:

$$J = \Delta p$$
This relationship is known as the impulse–momentum theorem.

concepts.title: Using the Impulse–Momentum Theorem
concepts.body: The impulse–momentum theorem can be used to calculate force, time of contact, or change in momentum for motion in one dimension.

concepts.title: Impulse and Safety
concepts.body: Increasing the time over which momentum changes reduces the force experienced. This explains safety devices such as airbags, seatbelts, and arrestor beds.
